node.text:
From a very early age, African-American civil rights icon and #UnitedNations leader, Ralph Bunche understood the pain and peril of racism.

Yet Bunche turned those experiences into a catalyst for change on the international stage, pursuing a legendary career as one of the most senior diplomatic officials of his time. 

From walking side-by-side with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., to working for peace as a UN mediator in Palestine, watch and learn more about the Nobel Prize Laureate. 

#FightRacism

node.title: Hero for Justice on the World's Stage

node.text:
"Because of climate change we are seeing even more intense storms, rising sea levels and many deaths. But we don’t have to accept this – we can act - and we must act as a matter of justice."

Environmentalist Sunita Narain explains why it's important that all of us #ActNow to achieve the goals of the #ParisAgreement. 

"Every country, rich or poor, is exposed to extreme weather. We need to build better and more resilient infrastructure – from electricity grids to roads, bridges and buildings. All these approaches are set out in the Paris Climate Agreement – adopted by nearly 200 countries. We can do it – we must do it – and we must act quickly."

From recycling to using less energy and water to opting for public transport, each and every one of us can take little steps in our everyday lives that can have a big impact. Tell us in the comments what you are doing to protect our planet.

#ClimateAction #GlobalGoals

node.text:
"We don’t have to choose between using energy and protecting the planet."

@unep Young Champion of the Earth Nzambi Matee explains the role sustainable energy plays in building a better future for all. 
 
"Imagine a world where every job is based on clean, renewable energy – and where wind and solar are even more abundant. And where energy is affordable and reliable – and available to everyone. This might sound like a fantasy – but it’s achievable and we know how to get there."

The #ParisAgreement on the climate emergency is our roadmap for moving to a low-carbon economy and achieving a sustainable future. Since this international #ClimateAction treaty opened for signature 5 years ago, almost 200 countries have signed on to tackle the climate crisis together to limit global warming to protect people and planet.

 #GlobalGoals #ActNow

node.text:
Cities are major contributors to the climate crisis, but also an important hub for #ClimateAction.

@UNEP Young Champion of the Earth Nzambi Matee explains what a green future for cities could look like & how the #ParisAgreement can help us get there.

node.text: Meet @unep Young Champion of the Earth Nzambi Matee. She's a Kenyan engineer taking #ClimateAction and helping to #BeatPlasticPollution by recycling plastic waste into building materials.

node.text:
"My warmest wishes to everyone celebrating #EidAlFitr," #UnitedNations Secretary-General @antonioguterres said on Wednesday.

"I was delighted to mark the end of Ramadan with Asia El-Sayeed Ali, a Yemeni health worker helping malnourished children and mothers in a @worldfoodprogramme-supported nutrition clinic.

Asia personifies core values of Ramadan: compassion and empathy. Her resilience in the face of the devastating conflict in Yemen, as well as her life-saving work in support of people in desperate need have moved me greatly.

As #Ramadan comes to an end, let us continue drawing inspiration from its many lessons of solidarity that are celebrated during this Holy Month."

Regram: @antonioguterres

node.text:
Regram: @antonioguterres

Young people are the most affected by the climate decisions taken today. Their ideas, voices and actions are crucial to deliver meaningful and ambitious #ClimateAction for all.

@pcopaloma and @mahery_loha are two inspiring climate activists who exemplify the leadership and commitment of young people worldwide to address the most challenging problems we face today.

I'm grateful for our discussion and their insights on how to achieve the meaningful participation of youth, women and indigenous peoples as we tackle the climate crisis.

#ActNow #GlobalGoals

node.text:
@unep Goodwill Ambassador @aidanrgallagher describes how the #ParisAgreement can help us create a world free from the threats of the climate crisis. 

"This is personal for me," he explains. "I don’t want to choke on the air I breathe, or see wildfires burning out of control. So let’s keep working together. And you too can protect what is left and repair what has been damaged."

On Thursday's #EarthDay, @antonioguterres will be joining the U.S. Leaders’ Summit on Climate to reiterate his call for urgent #ClimateAction. 

"The Paris Agreement is our pact with our children, grandchildren & the whole human family," said the Secretary-General. 

"The climate crisis is the race of our lifetimes. We must go much further, and much faster."

#GenerationRestoration #ForNature

node.text: On Monday's International Day of Human Space Flight, @europeanspaceagency astronaut @thom_astro became the newest @fao Goodwill Ambassador. He will use his voice and unique perspective from space to advocate for #ClimateAction and to help reduce hunger.

node.title: French astronaut Thomas Pesquet becomes newest @fao Goodwill Ambassador

node.text:
All children have the right to a happy and healthy childhood, free from discrimination and full of love and acceptance. And acceptance begins at home. Every child should grow up in safe, loving and nurturing environment.

No child should suffer because of who they are. All children deserve protection and equal rights. Let's see kids the way they see themselves.

On Wednesday's International Transgender Day of Visibility, join @unaidsglobal in calling for the rights of transgender children to be protected.

#TransDayOfVisibility #SeeMeAsIAm

node.text:
Six years since the start of the conflict, millions of Yemenis are in need of humanitarian assistance. Over four million are displaced within the country. 

Our colleagues from UNHCR, the #UnitedNations Refugees Agency, are in #Yemen providing aid, but they cannot do it alone. 

Please click the link in the @refugees' bio to help. 

#YemenCantWait

node.text:
Maya (@ghazalmia) fled Damascus, #Syria at age 16 and overcame numerous barriers to become the world’s first female Syrian refugee pilot. 

Check out her inspiring story!

#WithRefugees

node.title: Meet Maya Ghazal, the newest @refugees Goodwill Ambassador

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 18, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people sitting and indoor.

node.text:
"Bring the benefits of space to humankind - to everyone, everywhere - so that no one is left behind."

Simonetta Di Pippo, the first female director of the @europeanspaceagency and now @unoosa chief, is the first guest of Season 4 of our podcast, Awake At Night with #UnitedNations Global Communications chief @melissarfleming. 

Simonetta's work has been integral in using space for our common well-being here on Earth - from monitoring soil and water so farmers can grow healthier crops to tracking climate change using satellites. 

Check out the insightful conversation as she shares her passion for space, including her thoughts on the importance of preserving it as a global good benefiting all humanity.

Subscribe wherever you get your podcasts. 

Regram: @melissarfleming I 📸: UNIS Vienna / Nikoleta Haffar

#ClimateAction #GlobalGoals

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
Wednesday marks three years since the passing of former UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan, who was regarded by so many as a guiding force for good.

"People of different religions and cultures live side by side in almost every part of the world, and most of us have overlapping identities which unite us with very different groups. We can love what we are, without hating what -- and who -- we are not. We can thrive in our own tradition, even as we learn from others, and come to respect their teachings," Kofi Annan said in 2001, as he received the @nobelprize_org for Peace together with the #UnitedNations for "their efforts in favour of a better organized and more peaceful world."

📷: UN Photo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 7 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
Women play a critical role in achieving lasting peace around the world.

Women in #UnitedNations Peacekeeping missions help reduce conflict, serve as role models, provide a greater sense of security, and much more.

@unpeacekeeping is working to ensure women's full, equal and meaningful participation in peace and political processes.

👉 Scroll through to see photos of women peacekeepers working with the UN peacekeeping missions in Mali (MINUSMA), the Central African Republic (MINUSCA), and the former UN mission in Liberia (UNMIL).

📸: @un_minusca, @un_minusma, UN Photo/Christopher Herwig

#ServingForPeace #GlobalGoals #A4P

node.text:
#UnitedNations Secretary-General @antonioguterres addresses the Security Council meeting on #Afghanistan on Monday. 

"We cannot and must not abandon the people of Afghanistan," he said, urging the international community to stand, work and act together to uphold human rights for all and ensure the country is never again used as a safe haven for terrorists. 

"I am particularly concerned by accounts of mounting human rights violations against the women and girls of Afghanistan who fear a return to the darkest days," he added. "It is essential that the hard-won rights of Afghan women and girls are protected."

The Secretary-General stressed that the UN remains committed to supporting the people of Afghanistan: "We will stay and deliver in support of the Afghan people in their hour of need."

📸: UN Photo / Manuel Elias 

#StandUp4HumanRights #GlobalGoals

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 16, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, suit and text that says 'SECRETARY-GENERAL'.
Photo by United Nations on August 16, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and indoor.
Photo by United Nations on August 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'All abuses must stop.'.

node.text:
Regram @antonioguterres: 

I am deeply concerned about the situation in #Afghanistan, where conflict is forcing hundreds of thousands to flee amid reports of serious human rights violations.

All abuses must stop.

I urge the Taliban and all other parties to exercise utmost restraint to protect lives and ensure humanitarian needs can be met.

International humanitarian law and human rights, especially the hard-won gains of women and girls, must be preserved.

The #UnitedNations remains determined to contribute to a peaceful settlement, to promote human rights of all Afghans and to continue providing life-saving humanitarian support.

Regram: @antonioguterres

#StandUp4HumanRights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 15, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, child, people standing, people sitting and outdoors.

node.text:
7-year-olf Arifa holds her little sister in a camp for people displaced by conflict in Kandahar, #Afghanistan.

Across the country, more than 400,000 people have been forced to flee their homes, seeking refuge from the threat of bombs, bullets and rockets. Over half of them are children.

Amid #COVID19 and ongoing violence, @unicef has stepped up efforts to deliver life-saving water and health supplies to those most in need.

Regram: @unicef I 📷: UNICEF/UN0498790/UNICEF Afghanistan

#ForEveryChild #GlobalGoals

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 15, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and outdoors.

node.text:
Rowshan and Shahidul rest with their two daughters under a mosquito net on a boat, their temporary home in #Bangladesh.

In early 2020, the young parents lost the only land they owned to river erosion. Not long after they rebuilt their house, it was submerged in a second round of flooding. Their situation has been further exacerbated by intense monsoons and the impact of the climate crisis.

Time is running out for millions of people like Rowshans and Shaidull, who are already losing their lives, homes, and livelihoods to the climate emergency. They have contributed the least to the global crisis, yet they are being hit the hardest.

The @worldfoodprogramme (WFP) is supporting Rowshans and Shaidull, so that the family is able to buy food. WFP is working with partners to improve weather forecasting and flood data in Bangladesh, so people can prepare ahead floodwaters or other weather disasters.⠀
⠀
Regram: @un_ocha | 📷 WFP / Sayed Asif Mahmud

#TheHumanRace #ClimateAction #GlobalGoals

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 14, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, animal and grass.

node.text:
A young girl from #Colombia gently pets a calf in the Andes mountains of #Ecuador.

"When I grow up, I want to be a veterinarian," she says. Her family is among the nearly 70,000 Colombian refugees who fled their homes in search of a better future. Amid the pandemic, Ecuador has granted all people access to public health services, regardless of nationality or residency status. 

Yet, refugees in isolated and remote parts of the country still struggle to reach medical facilities, while others are unaware of their rights.

The #UnitedNations Refugee Agency (UNHCR) is working to provide humanitarian assistance in Ecuador, including by monitoring #COVID19 cases among the refugee and migrant populations, delivering health services and medical equipment, and more.

Regram: @refugees  I 📷: © UNHCR/Sebastián Narváez

#WithRefugees #GlobalGoals

node.text:
A #UnitedNations stamps depicts Mother Teresa with the quote: “Not all of us can do great things. But we can do small things with great love.”

The Nobel Laureate dedicated her life to helping some of the world's most vulnerable people for more than four decades.

The new set of commemorative stamps is honouring her life and legacy in service of humanity.

📷: @unstamps / Martin Mörck

node.text:
A demining specialist with the #UnitedNations Mine Action Service (UNMAS) carries out vital work to protect civilians in #Afghanistan.

Decades of war have taken an immeasurable toll on the country. Afghanistan is one of the countries most affected by landmines and explosive remnants of war in the world. 

More than 40,000 Afghan civilians have been killed or injured by explosive hazards since 1989. The current escalation of conflict in the country has resulted in further and new types of explosives contamination.

Around the world, members of UNMAS put their lives at risk to reduce danger and protect people from the physical and psychological harm caused by landmines and explosive remnants of war.

Regram: @un_mineaction I 📸: UNMAS

node.text:
A biker passes fragments of the #BerlinWall in #Germany. 

Friday marks 60 years since construction began on the wall, which fell in 1989. 

"While the wall has been long torn down, artificial divisions continue to be built in too many places," said #UnitedNations Secretary-General @antonioguterres on the anniversary. "Let's never lose sight of our power to dismantle them and our ability to create a better world."

📷: UN Social Media / @missfotos 

 #GlobalGoals #StandUp4HumanRights

node.text:
19-year-old Houleye is a bright young woman from a small village in #Mauritania.

When she participated in a digital skills vocational training course supported by the World Food Programme (WFP), she took her very first photo, which unveiled an untapped talent. 

The first time Houleye saw her photo of a woman preparing lunch for school children, she was incredibly happy and proud to have taken such an authentic and emblematic photo in her village.

Houleye is among 20 women who participated in the storytellers training course, which has helped them share images of resilience and strength in their communities.

Regram: @worldfoodprogramme 

#GlobalGoals
